A. 
 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

1. 

Road Infrastructure 

 
Afghanistan is a landlocked country. With a large area (about 652,000 square kilometers 
2. 
[km2]) and an estimated population of 22.8 million widely spread across the largely mountainous 
terrain, roads are the principal means of transport. Its road network comprises about 6,100 km 
of  national  roads,  15,000  km  of  provincial  roads,  15,000–20,000  km  of  rural  roads,  and  about 
3,000 km of urban roads including 1,060 km in Kabul. Of the national roads, 3,300 km comprise 
national primary roads forming part of the 2,300 km ring road that connects Afghanistan’s major 
regional centers (Herat, Kandahar, Maimana, Mazar-e-Sharif, and Sheberghan) with Kabul, and 
the roads leading to neighboring countries. The remaining 2,800 km of national roads constitute 
secondary roads with gravel or earthen surface. The 15,000 km provincial roads have gravel or 
earthen surface and comprise 5,400 km of provincial primary roads and 9,600 km of provincial 
secondary roads 
 
Much  of  Afghanistan’s  road  infrastructure  was  destroyed  or  damaged  during  the  more 
3. 
than two decades of conflict. Lack of resources and capacity prevented maintenance and has 
led to major deterioration and loss of infrastructure. A comprehensive needs assessment of the 
Afghanistan  transport  sector 1   by  major  external  funding  agencies  including  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) revealed that 54%  of national roads were in poor condition, 26% in 
fair condition, and only 20% in good condition. The needs assessment recommended that the 
entire primary road network be rehabilitated on a priority basis. 
 
Afghanistan’s road network is characterized by very low road density. The road density 
4. 
of  0.03  km/km2  is  far  lower  than  that  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  Tajikistan,  which  also  have 
largely  mountainous  terrain  and  similar  population  density,  and  is  even  lower  than  that  of 
Balochistan  in  Pakistan,  where  population  density  is  about  half  that  of  Afghanistan. 2  Even 
without  the  damage  inflicted  during  the  conflict  period,  Afghanistan’s  road  network  needs 
substantial improvement to provide the Afghan population with a basic level of connectivity.

representing an almost fourfold increase. The number of taxicabs nearly doubled from 17,000 in

7. 
Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  provided  mostly  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans. Forms of regional transport depend on the state of 
the  roads  and  the  availability  of  vehicles.  People  and  goods  move  together,  blurring  the

3. 

Road Sector Management 

 
8. 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW)  has  been  responsible  for  developing,  operating, 
and  maintaining  of  the  primary  and  secondary  road  network  in  the  country.  MPW  had  an 
institutional  setup  of  a  large  engineering  organization  with  staff  stationed  in  every  major 
provincial capital and carrying out work through force account. Over the course of the conflict, 
MPW  lost  the  majority  of  its  trained  staff.  The  current  staff  of  2,900  require  substantial  skills 
enhancement  to  perform  their  duties.  The  Ministry  of  Rehabilitation  and  Rural  Development  is 
responsible  for  developing  of  rural  infrastructure,  including  rural  roads.  Construction  and 
maintenance of urban roads are the responsibility of municipalities. 
 
9. 
MOT  regulates  the  private  sector  transport  industry.  MOT’s  primary  function  is 
coordinating  agreements  between  the  private  sector  and  international  transporters  and 
establishing  eight  offices  in  neighboring  countries  to  facilitate  international  trade.  The  private 
sector department in MOT sets technical standards for private commercial vehicles and inspects 
them for compliance during licensing and renewal of license. It collects a fee of 5% per carriage 
contract  from  private  trucks  and  3%  per  trip  from  interprovincial  private  buses,  based  on 
authorized charge rates.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

 

B. 
 

1. 

Government Strategy for Road Sector Development  

 
The  Government  declared  that  rehabilitation  of  the  road  system,  especially  of  national 
11. 
primary  roads,  is  the  country’s  top  priority  in  reconstruction.  With  external  assistance,  since 
2002 the Government has been making massive efforts to reestablish the road network, so as 
to facilitate provision of basic social services to remote provinces, provide security, and involve 
all the population in undertaking nation-building activities. 
 

  

3

Currently,  capital  investment  to  rehabilitate  and  reconstruct  roads  in  Afghanistan  is 
12. 
financed  mainly  by  external  assistance.  The  current  commitments  of  external 
bilateral/multilateral funding agencies to Afghanistan’s road sector amount to approximately 
$1  billion,  including  $800  million  for  national  primary  roads,  $130  million  for  national 
secondary  roads,  and  $30  million  for  provincial  roads.  These  commitments  are  mainly  to 
rehabilitate damaged roads. 
 
For  improving  the  road  network,  the  Government  has  set  a  target  to  double  the 
13. 
share of total paved roads from the present 16% to 32% by 2010, or from the present 0.15 
km  of  paved  road  per  1,000  people  to  0.23  km  per  1,000  in  2010.  To  reach  this  target, 
investment needs from 2004 to 2010 will be for $4.3 billion outside the existing commitment: 
$1.7  billion  for  national  primary  roads,  $1.1  billion  for  national  secondary  roads,  and  $1.5 
billion for provincial roads.4 Considering the limited prospect for private sector financing of 
these large investments in the foreseeable future, the public sector and external assistance 
will continue to be responsible for filling the financing gap. 
 
14. 
Afghanistan  has  a  history  of  toll  collection  for  road  maintenance.  The  first  toll  system 
was  implemented  in  1974.  Tolls  were  collected  by  way  of  a  system  of  toll  stations  scattered 
throughout the country, and the revenue accrued to the central revenue fund with no earmarking 
for the road sector. A new system implemented in 1999 introduced earmarking the toll revenue 
for  construction  and  maintenance  of  highways.  Through  a  decision  of  the  High  Council  of 
Ministers on 23 September 2002, however, this road toll system was abolished. Approximately 
$80  million  is  estimated  to  be  required  annually  to  maintain  the  entire  road  network.  For  a 
country with total domestic revenues of only $300 million, that cost will be a challenge. While the 
Government  is  in  the  process  of  establishing  a  fuel  tax  regime  to  support  road  maintenance 
funding, it is also considering reinstating toll collection on improved road sections5 to cover the 
maintenance cost as well as to recover part of the capital investment cost. ADB is providing, as 
part  of  the  master  plan  Technical  Assistance  (TA) 6 ,  support  in  formulating  financing 
mechanisms for road sector expenditure.

reconstructing, and developing of the road sector consists of the following elements: (i) policies 
and  institutions  developing;  (ii)  building  capacity;  (iii)  developing  the  private  sector;  (iv) 
generating  employment;  (v)  encourage  community  participation;  (vi)  decentralizing  of  network 
management; (vii) promoting sustainable sector financing and cost recovery; (viii) protection and 
preserving  the  environment;  (ix)  avoiding  and  mitigating  resettlement;  (x)  absorbing  returnee 
refugees,  ex-combatants,  and  women

External Assistance  

 
18.

Opium-Related Problems 

 
35. 
Afghanistan  is  the  world’s  largest  producer  of  illicit  opium,  comprising  87%  of  world 
production,  or  some  4,200  metric  t.  Narcotics  also  constitute  the  largest  sector  of  the  Afghan 
economy.  Valued  at  $2.8  billion,  the  opium  economy  equals  some  60%  of  the  country’s  2003 
gross domestic product ($4.6 billion, if only licit activity is measured). Opium is a major source of 
cash income for farmers because of the high profitability of opium poppy compared with other 
agricultural crops as well as the lack of livelihood alternatives. According to the United Nations 
Office  on  Drugs  and  Crime  (UNODC),  in  2004  poppy  cultivation  in  Afghanistan  hit  an  all-time 
high, with 52,400 hectares under cultivation (only 2.9% of total agricultural land). Although this 
represented a 64% increase over 2003 cultivation, total production increased by only 17% due 
to  bad  weather  and  crop  disease.  In  2004  opium  poppy  was  grown  in  all  of  Afghanistan’s  34 
provinces,  up  from  only  28  provinces  in  2003.  UNODC  estimates  that  356,000  Afghan 
households  are  involved  in  opium  poppy  cultivation,  representing  some  2.3  million  people,  or 
10%  of  the  country’s  total  population,  with  each  household  cultivating  an  average  of  0.37 
hectare (ha) of opium poppy.  
 
36. 
UNODC’s  February  2005  Rapid  Opium  Poppy  Assessment  Survey  revealed  a  falling 
trend  in  opium  poppy  cultivation  in  most  provinces,  mainly  because  farmers  refrained  from 
planting. The main reasons reported by villagers for the expected reduction in cultivation were 
respect  for  a  Government  ban  on  opium  poppy  cultivation  and  fear  of  eradication.  In  some 
areas, villagers indicated that the low yields of opium poppy in 2004 influenced their decision, as 
well as increased wheat prices.   
 
Poppy  cultivation  and  downstream  narcotics  production  and  trade  constitute  a  major 
37. 
threat to Afghanistan’s security and stability in that the trade in opium, including opium debt, ties 
the poor rural population to regional warlords and international crime syndicates. No country can 
establish  a  sustainable,  accountable  government  and  security  structure  when  nearly  half  its 
economy is based on the production of an illegal crop. To address the multifactored problem of 
narcotics  production,  the  Government  in  October  2002  established  a  Counter  Narcotics 
Directorate to coordinate national policies and programs for drug control, and adopted an Anti-
Narcotics Law in 2003. The Directorate was elevated to a full ministry in December 2004. Also 
in December 2004 President Hamid Karzai called for a jihad (holy war) on narcotics production, 
resulting in some crop eradication activities. 
 
38. 
The  Government’s  overall  anti-narcotics  strategy  is  to  eliminate  the  production, 
consumption,  and  trafficking  of  illicit  drugs  into,  within,  and  from  Afghanistan,  with  focus  on 
providing  alternative  livelihood  for  Afghan  poppy  farmers,  extending  drug  law  enforcement 
throughout Afghanistan, implementing drug control legislation, establishing effective institutions, 
and introducing of prevention and treatment programs for addicts. Aid agencies are contributing 
to  the  Government’s  anti-narcotics  efforts  with  focus  on  alternative  livelihoods,  including  rural 
credit to address the problem of opium debt, as well as support for improved law enforcement 
and interdiction and legal and judicial reform. Aid agencies also are attempting to  mainstream 
the  anti-narcotics  agenda  into  other  development  activities,  and  recently  have  developed  an 
anti-narcotics  checklist  or  screen  to  promote  such  mainstreaming.  During  the  second  half  of 
2005,  ADB  will  use  this  checklist  to  review  its  activities  in  Afghanistan,  including  its  road  and 
transport projects.  
 
Although irregular border crossings currently are preferred for illegal trafficking, as formal

border  crossings  improve  and  as  volumes  of  cargo  and  passengers  increase,  the  volume  of 
narcotics  trafficked  by  way  of  formal  border  crossings  and  through  the  main  roads  is  likely  to

40. 
It  is  noted,  however,  that  the  goal  of  counternarcotics  in  Afghanistan  is  to  building 
stability and the rule of law. Hence the measure of success is not only reducing the amount of 
opium  poppy  grown  by  Afghan  farmers,  but  curtailing  the  flow  of  income  and  accumulation  of 
wealth by traffickers and commanders while maintaining adequate growth in the legal economy. 
It  is  also  noted  that  opium  cultivation  is  the  only  means  by  which  many  farmers  can  obtain

significantly reduce travel time and cost, turning the painful road trip along that road into a safe 
single-day daylight trip.

Afghanistan’s road network comprises about 6,100 kilometers (km) of national roads and 
1.

2. 
Most  of  the  national  primary  road  network  was  improved  to  paved  standard  before  the 
conflict,  mainly  with  external  assistance.  The  ring  road  section  from  the  border  of  Jawzjan-

3. 
Much of Afghanistan’s road infrastructure was destroyed or damaged in more than two 
decades  of  conflict.  Lack  of  resources  and  capacity  prevented  maintenance,  and  has  led  to 
major  deterioration  and  loss  of  infrastructure.  The  effects  of  military  actions  are  more 
pronounced in the form of damaged bridges and tunnels, which have become bottlenecks to the 
movement  of  people  and  goods.  Restricted  movement  aggravates  the  country’s  division  and 
disintegration, as travel time and vehicle operating cost on roads have significantly increased.1 
  
According to the comprehensive needs assessment on the Afghanistan transport sector,

Currently,  capital  investment  to  rehabilitate  and  reconstruct  roads  in  Afghanistan  is

damaged roads.  
 
15. 
For the improvement of the road network, the Government has set a target to double the 
share of total paved roads from the present 16% to 32% by 2010, or from the present 0.15 km 
of  paved  roads  per  1,000  people  to  0.23  km  per  1,000  in  2010.  To  reach  this  target,  the  new 
investment  needs  from  2004  to  2010  will  be  for  $4.3  billion  outside  the  existing  commitment:

investments in the foreseeable future, the public sector will continue to be responsible for filling 
the financing gap.  
 
16. 
Afghanistan  has  a  history  of  toll  collection  for  road  maintenance.  The  first  toll  system 
was  implemented  in  1974.  Tolls  were  collected  by  way  of  a  system  of  toll  stations  scattered 
throughout the country, and the revenue accrued to the central revenue fund with no earmarking 
for the road subsector. The allocations to the road subsector were by way of appropriations from 
the central revenue fund. A new system implemented in 1999 introduced earmarking the funds 
for construction and maintenance of highways. MPW organized toll collection and the tolls were 
viewed as a source of MPW revenue. Through a decision by the High Council of Ministers on 23 
September  2002,  this  road  toll  system  was  abolished.  Private  parties  had  established 
unauthorized  toll  collection  stations  in  a  number  of  locations,  which  created  hardships  for 
travelers without contributing to the maintenance program.  
 
17. 
At  present,  fuel,  spares,  or  vehicles  are  not  taxed,  except  for  customs  duties.  Some 
fees/levies  are  charged  by  the  Ministry  of  Interior  and  the  Provincial  Finance  Department  for 
vehicle registration and renewal.

be required to fully implement the new tax regime. In the meantime, imposing tolls, in particular 
on roads that have recently been rehabilitated, is viewed as an effective way to generate much-
needed  revenue  for  road-related  expenditure.  Approximately  $80  million  is  estimated  to  be 
required annually to maintain the entire road network. For a country with domestic revenues of 
$300  million,  this  will  be  a  challenge.  The  Government  is  currently  considering  reinstating  toll 
collection on improved road sections5 to cover the maintenance cost as well as to recover part 
of the capital investment cost.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan: 
 
The  Government  of  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Afghanistan  has  accorded  highest  priority  to  the  development  of  road 
infrastructure. Because it is recognizes of the importance of an efficient, reliable road network in a landlocked country 
and its contribution to poverty reduction. The inadequate road system keeps many farmers dependent on subsistence 
agriculture with no, or limited, access to markets, education, and health care. The project road (90 km) from Qaisar to 
Bala Murghab is part of the 550 km stretch of road between Herat and Andkhoy, which runs through one of the most 
remote  and  least  developed  areas  of  the  country.  The  existing  road  was  never  paved  and  is  merely  a  track  of  mud 
road where most sections easily turn impassable after the rains. Rehabilitating and improving this road to a standard 
allowing easy motor vehicle movement will complete the missing link of the ring road and facilitate political integration 
of  the  country,  contributing  to  employment  creation,  and  income  generation  for  poor  households,  rehabilitation  of 
internally  and/or  internationally  displaced  persons  and  ex-combatants. The  road  will  also  open  up  a  trade  route  that 
connects  the  northern  part  of  Afghanistan  and  neighboring  Uzbekistan  and  Tajikistan  to  the  western  part  of  the 
country, and further to Iran, forming a subregional road transport corridor. The project proposes to utilize, to the extent 
possible,  labor-intensive  construction  methods  to  provide  much-needed  employment  and  income-generating 
opportunities  during  project  implementation,  and  use  the  services  of  the  local  population  for  the  post-construction 
maintenance  activities.  It  will  contribute  to  social  stability  and  poverty  reduction  by  engaging,  among  others  the 
refugees  and  ex-combatants.  Thus,  the  investment  is  expected  to  significantly  improve  the  socioeconomic  situation 
and mitigate the pervasive poverty in the project area.  

 
 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                            Poverty Classification:  General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
In Afghanistan, approximately 53% of the population are classified as poor1 and live on less than $1 a day.  The road 
passes  through  the  provinces  of  Faryab  and  Badghis  and  the  project  influence  area  is  known  to  be  drought  prone. 
People  have  traditionally  grown  poppy  because  the  absence  of  a  good  road  and  public  transport  system  prevents 
them from selling their marketable crop surpluses. The prolonged war in the country further aggravated by drought has 
severely  affected  the  livelihood  sources  of  the  local  population.  Only  in  areas  such  as  Gormach,  Bala  Murghab  in 
Badghis Province, where some irrigation facilities are available due to the presence of a flowing river, people cultivate 
wheat and watermelon instead of poppy.2 Decreased farm productivity due to prolonged drought has been the norm; 
however, this year’s monsoons have been unprecedented in the last 20 years and farmers have farmed even hilltops 
and  desert  lands.  The  sample  household  survey  and  consultations  carried  out  revealed  that  almost  90%  of  the 
households were engaged in subsistence agriculture and allied activities for their livelihood, while the rest had small 
businesses in the towns. Only in the Qaisar region are cash crops like raisins grown with marketable surpluses. The 
survey also revealed that the households in the project area are extremely poor, with an average monthly income of 
approximately AF2,000 and an average household size of 5.5. Households near the Bala Murghab section of the road 
do not have cash income, as the crops they grow are not even sufficient for their consumption. Thus, reduced farm 
productivity and loss of seasonal opportunities for agriculture labor are two of the main determinants of poverty in the 
area. 
 
Afghanistan ranks the 4th highest in mortality of those under five at 257 deaths/1,000. The infant mortality rate is at a 
high 165/1,000.The survey also indicated that there  were  no government hospitals or primary health care centers in 
the four towns (Kaizar, Chechaktu, Chilgasi, and Gormach) to be traversed by the project road.  The local population 
depend primarily on private clinics present in the four towns for minor ailments or routine checkups. For any serious 
illness, they hire private vehicles and travel 3–8 hours by road to reach the two provincial capitals of Qalai-Naw and 
Maimana to avail themselves of better health care facilities. Due to lack of a public transport system in the area, the 
rental  charges  of  private  vehicles  are  extremely  high  and  thus  health  care  is  considered  an  expensive  proposition. 
Lack of adequate educational facilities was also another major problem in the project area. Although the towns of both 
Qaisar  and  Gormach  had  primary  and  secondary  schools,  Gormach,  which  was  worse  affected  during  the  Taliban 
regime,  did  not  have  teachers  and,  consequently,  no  students.  Poor  road  conditions  and  accessibility  and  lack  of 
security in the project area discourage teachers from other parts of Afghanistan from working in this region.

traffic.
